awd_titl_txt: Conference: International Conference on Linguistics Communication
awd_abstract_narration:
A critical part of doing science is communicating results to the general public in an effective manner. However, scientists often do not have opportunities for training in how to connect with the public and they are often unfamiliar with the range of methods that they could use to reach them. The purpose of the International Conference on Linguistics Communication is to bring together language scientists, their students, and expert science communicators with two core goals in mind: (1) To improve the public engagement skills of the scientists and (2) To connect academic scientists with a network of communication experts who have a proven interest in promoting language science. 

The conference is held completely online to keep the event cost-effective and to allow easy participation from scientists and communicators from around the globe. The scientists come from every level of seniority, from highly distinguished scholars to very junior students; moreover, they conduct research on a wide variety of language related topics. The professional communicators engage the public in many different ways, including writing magazine articles, running podcasts, creating video content, and doing in-person events at festivals and museums. The conference provides opportunities for the scientists to learn key skills involved in communicating with the public in different ways. It also provides networking opportunities to help scientists and professional communicators work together. In general, the conference aims to inspire scientists to value public communication, to encourage scientists to forge ties beyond their usual academic environments, and to expand the ways that language science results reach the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The International Conference on Linguistics Communication (LingComm) brought together a unique combination of university academics who engage with the public and professionals who specialize in how to communicate with the public about language.  The all-online conference featured sessions that provided practical advice, such as how to start a podcast, and how to use tiktok to effectively connect with the public; other sessions showcased best practices for working in schools and museum settings; and other sessions highlighted new and creative ways to reach the public, including a session on artistic endeavors.

 

Roughly 150 people attended the conference, including university faculty, professional communicators, students, and avid amateur communicators – that is, individuals who engage in ongoing communication activities (such as running podcasts) but don’t get paid enough for it to be their primary job.  In addition, thanks to the on-line format of the conference, attendees came from around the world, with strong attendance coming from Germany and Brazil.

 

Engaging the public in an effective and accessible way is an important part of the scientific process: it is how results can be translated into something that can be used by society.  In the case of language science, the results of the field have implications for how we educate our children, how we build our technology, and how we can best support individuals in our society who speak different languages and dialects.  The scientists who create the critical results in the field, however, rarely receive training in how to effectively communicate it with the public. Moreover, there are few venues where academic scientists can get professional credit when they do engage with the public.

 

The LingComm conference provided a space where academics could be inspired to engage with the public, learn how to improve their skills in accessible communication, and network with communication professionals in mutually beneficial ways.  In addition, the conference itself provided a form of professional credit, as academics who presented at it could list the event on their CV.   More broadly, the conference helped to solidify a community of individuals, critically including both academic researchers and professional communicators, that are committed to working together to promote language science to the general public and to create opportunities for others to do effectively engage with the public.

 

Finally, oneof the goals of this project was to develop the infrastructure – tools, templates, resources – to ensure that this conference would become a regular event.  It is a pleasure to report that organizers for a 2025 iteration of the conference have stepped up and the LingComm conference will continue in the future.
